skill.name: when-documenting-code-use-doc-generator
skill.description: Automated comprehensive code documentation generation with API docs, README files, inline comments, and architecture diagrams
skill.summary: Automated comprehensive code documentation generation with API docs, README files, inline comments, ...
skill.author: DNYoussef

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation generation skill with no network access or credential exposure. Shell scripts are read-only analysis tools that generate local markdown files within the project directory.

content.value_statement: Writing documentation for codebases takes significant time and is often skipped. This skill automatically generates API documentation, README files, inline comments, and architecture diagrams from source code analysis.
actual_capabilities: Generate OpenAPI 3.0 specifications from source code
Create comprehensive README.md files with project metadata
Add JSDoc and docstring comments to undocumented functions
Produce architecture diagrams using Graphviz format
Analyze code structure and identify documentation gaps
Validate documentation coverage and generate reports
limitations: Does not execute or modify code logic
Generated documentation requires human review for accuracy
Limited to supported languages (JS, TS, Python, Java, Go, Rust)

use_cases.title: Document Your Project
use_cases.description: Generate complete documentation for public repositories to improve usability and attract contributors

use_cases.title: Create API Reference
use_cases.description: Automatically generate OpenAPI specs and markdown docs for REST APIs built with Express, FastAPI, or NestJS

use_cases.title: Standardize Documentation
use_cases.description: Enforce documentation standards across codebases with automated comment generation and coverage reporting

prompt_templates.title: Generate All Docs
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate comprehensive documentation for this project including API docs, README, inline comments, and architecture diagrams

prompt_templates.title: API Documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate OpenAPI 3.0 specification and markdown documentation for all REST endpoints in this project

prompt_templates.title: Inline Comments
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this codebase and add JSDoc comments to all undocumented public functions

prompt_templates.title: Project README
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a comprehensive README.md for this project based on package.json and project structure

output_examples.input: Generate documentation for my Express API project
output: Run /doc-inline to add more inline comments

best_practices: Review and customize generated documentation before committing
Add real-world usage examples to complement auto-generated ones
Use pre-commit hooks to maintain documentation coverage
anti_patterns: Do not rely solely on auto-generated docs without human review
Avoid generating docs for untested or unstable APIs
Do not skip documentation for complex business logic
Avoid generic descriptions that do not explain function purpose

faq.question: Which programming languages are supported?
faq.answer: JavaScript (JSDoc), TypeScript (TSDoc), Python (Google/NumPy), Java (JavaDoc), Go (GoDoc), Rust (RustDoc), and C# (XML)

faq.question: What is the minimum documentation coverage target?
faq.answer: Default target is 80% coverage for public functions. Configure in docs.json config file.

faq.question: Can this skill integrate with CI/CD pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, use GitHub Actions workflow to generate and validate docs on every push to main branch.

faq.question: Does this skill send data to external servers?
faq.answer: No, all documentation is generated locally. No network calls are made to external services.

faq.question: Why are my diagrams not rendering?
faq.answer: Install Graphviz: brew install graphviz (macOS), sudo apt install graphviz (Ubuntu), or choco install graphviz (Windows).

faq.question: How is this different from JSDoc or TypeDoc?
faq.answer: This skill generates broader project documentation including README files, architecture diagrams, and API specs beyond just inline comments.
